message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a rotator cuff injury indicated by the MRI, which is commonly treated with NSAIDs and conservative measures such as rest and ice. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection and acromioplasty are options for more severe cases, but not the best initial course of treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient most likely has rotator cuff tendinopathy, and NSAIDs and conservative measures such as rest and ice are the best initial course of treatment. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered for persistent symptoms, and acromioplasty is usually reserved for cases with significant structural abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history, physical examination, and MRI findings indicate rotator cuff tendinitis, which generally responds well to NSAIDs and conservative measures such as rest and ice. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered for more severe cases, but it is not the best initial course of treatment. Acromioplasty is a surgical option that may be considered for refractory cases, but it is not indicated as the initial course of treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and imaging findings suggest a rotator cuff injury. NSAIDs can reduce pain and inflammation and is the best initial course of treatment for this patient, in addition to conservative measures such as rest, ice, and physical therapy. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered if conservative measures are not effective, and acromioplasty is a surgical treatment option for chronic or severe rotator cuff injuries.

NSAIDs and conservative measures such as rest and ice are the initial treatment options for rotator cuff injuries. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection and acromioplasty may be considered if conservative measures fail.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and imaging findings suggest rotator cuff tendinitis. Conservative measures such as rest and ice may help but NSAIDs can also provide pain relief and reduce inflammation. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered if conservative measures and NSAIDs do not provide sufficient relief, but it is not the best initial course of treatment. Acromioplasty is a surgical option for rotator cuff tendinitis but is not the best initial course of treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with pain and limited range of motion in his right shoulder, with tenderness to palpation on the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder. The MRI reveals increased signals in the rotator cuff tendon, which is indicative of rotator cuff tendinopathy. Conservative measures (rest and ice) alone may not be enough to alleviate the symptoms. NSAIDs are effective in reducing pain and inflammation, and can be used in conjunction with conservative measures to improve the patient’s symptoms. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection can also be considered, but is typically reserved for cases that do not respond to NSAIDs and conservative measures. Acromioplasty is a surgical procedure that is only considered in cases of severe or chronic rotator cuff tendinopathy that do not respond to non-surgical measures.

The patient has symptoms of rotator cuff tendinitis, and among the options, NSAIDs and conservative measures will be the best initial course of treatment. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection is an option if conservative measures fail, while Acromioplasty is a surgical option used for severe cases of rotator cuff tendinitis.

Conservative measures are the first step in treatment, which includes rest and ice, as well as NSAIDs for pain relief. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may be considered if conservative measures are not effective. Acromioplasty is a surgery that is reserved for cases where conservative measures have failed.

Conservative measures such as rest and ice can be helpful, but NSAIDs can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection may also be used but is typically reserved for cases of severe symptoms that are unresponsive to conservative measures. Acromioplasty is a surgical procedure that may be considered in cases of chronic, refractory rotator cuff tendinitis, but it is not the initial course of treatment.
